Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Preparation and Characterization of New Heterogeneous Bimetallic Au-M Catalysts for Selective Oxidations and Hydrogenations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Bert D. Chandler from Trinity University to investigate the effects of adding heterometals to supported Au nanoparticle catalysts. New nanoparticle and catalyst synthesis techniques will be employed to prepare bimetallic nanoparticles on alumina and titania. Kinetics -based analytical techniques including (1) intentional poisoning studies to evaluate relative numbers of active sites, and (2) Hammett relationships to probe changes in NP surface charge will be developed and employed. These studies will enable a quantitative comparison of different catalysts, thus allowing for an assessment of heterometals effect on Au NPs, and answering fundamental questions regarding the nature of the catalytic active sites. Further, this program will provide numerous research opportunities for undergraduate students, giving them hands on experience in this nationally important area of research and training them to be the next generation of scientists.

Improving our fundamental understanding of bimetallic nanoparticles and their catalytic properties has the potential to positively impact both the U. S. catalysis industry and the national economy by providing cheaper materials and consumer products as well as reducing pollution and industrial waste. This includes finding new ways to assemble a few hundred metal atoms, which can be a difficult chemical synthesis problem. This project will expand the methods developed by the PI to produce nanoparticles that have an inexpensive metal at the core (Cu, Ni, Fe) and Au on the outside. These new nanoparticles will be deposited onto a support and used to catalyze a variety of reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Annually, the US produces more than 150 million tons of polyethylene and polypropylene polymers – these are incorporated into all manner of household products, including plastic bottles, fabrics, tote bags, food packaging, and garbage bags.  Polyethylene and polypropylene are polymers made from ethylene (C2H4) and propylene (C3H6) monomers, which are in a class of molecules called alkenes.  Alkenes are widely produced from petroleum, but can also be produced from natural gas.  However, alkene production from these sources is not perfect, and small amounts of acetylene (C2H2) and propyne (C3H4) are produced.  Although these molecules only differ from the desired molecules by two hydrogen atoms, they cause big problems in the processing required to convert the ethylene to polyethylene and propylene to polypropylene.  The most cost effective and environmentally friendly way to remove these molecules is to add H2 to (or hydrogenate) them, which converts them into the desired ethylene and propylene molecules.    

            This project worked to understand how to selectively hydrogenate alkynes to alkenes over Au nanoparticle catalysts, using octyne (C8H14) hydrogenation (to octene, C8H16) as a model reaction.  The difficulty with this reaction is that alkenes can also react quickly with hydrogen to make alkanes (e.g. ethane, propane, and octane).  This makes the reaction very difficult to control; because the reacting gas is mostly alkenes, it is hard to only fish out the alkynes while preventing the alkenes from reacting.  In terms of selecting for only reacting the alkynes, gold happens to be a very good material for this “selective” or “partial” hydrogenation reaction (alkyne to alkene).  However, gold has a problem:  it is a very slow hydrogenation catalyst.  This means that it takes a lot of catalyst to do the reaction; since Au is an expensive precious metal, it would be far more useful if we could find ways to improve the activity of Au catalysts for this reaction, while maintaining their high selectivity. 

            The long-term goal of his project was to develop catalysts that incorporate less expensive base metals (e.g. Ni, Co) into the catalyst to improve the activity of Au.  We first worked to understand the role of the underlying support on catalysis by Au nanoparticles, and developed a new method for evaluating the relative electron richness or poorness of the catalytic active site.  We also developed a new method for synthesizing supported Au catalysts, which allowed us to deposit nanoparticles of the same size onto a variety of different supports. 

We discovered that, at least for alkyne hydrogenation, the electron richness/poorness of the Au nanoparticles did not have a large impact on catalytic activity.  As we investigated the reaction mechanism, we showed that the key step in the reaction is the initial activation of hydrogen on the catalyst surface.  Previous studies assumed that hydrogen and alkynes competed for the catalyst active sites.  Our studies indicated that there is relatively little competition between the two reacting molecules, with each molecule being activated at different sites on the catalyst surface.  This was a surprising result, but one that helps us to consider new ways to improve these catalysts.

We also developed a new synthesis method for preparing Ni-Au bimetallic particles, which are notoriously difficult to prepare.  This is because Ni and Au do not form bulk alloys like, for example, Cu and Zn form alloys commonly known as brass.  We used new nanoparticle synthesis technique to prepare bimetallic nanoparticles in solution, then deposit them and remove the nanoparticle stabilizing agent.  We developed this synthesis around a nanoparticle stabilizing agent (oleylamine) because we were confident that it would be easy to remove to prepare reactive metal surfaces.  Our preliminary results showed that these new Ni-Au catalysts are 5-10 times more active than Au, but retain most of the high alkene selectivity.

Most importantly, this project offered numerous opportunities for undergraduates to participate in high-quality, meaningful research.  Eight undergraduates participated in the project including two women, one of whom is a first generation college student and the other is an African-American student.  Two of the male students were Hispanic, and both of them have gone on to graduate school in the sciences.  High quality research opportunities such as these are rare for students in the sciences, but have huge influence on their decisions of whether or not to pursue advanced degrees.  By doing high quality, peer-reviewed science with undergraduates, this project has helped to train the next generation of scientists, physicians, and engineers.  It has also helped send a number of scientifically literate employees into the workforce, where they use their understanding of the scientific process and reliance on data to benefit the US economy.
